Fig. 1 SEM images of (a) CeO2-C, (b) CeO2-R, and (c) CeO2-P; TEM images of (d) CeO2-C, (e) CeO2-R, and (f) CeO2-P; XRD patterns of (g) CeO2; (h) schematic illustration of the synthesis process of CeO2-C, CeO2-R, and CeO2-P. Graphical abstract The selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR) has a significant impact on the sustainable development of the environment. It is crucial to design efficient low-temperature catalysts to overcome the challenges associated with the industrialization of CO-SCR. Herein, we present CuO/CeO2 catalysts with three different exposed crystal facets of CeO2 ((100), (110), and (111)) synthesized by a hydrothermal method followed by impregnation for CO-SCR. Among the three CuO/CeO2 catalysts, CuO loaded on rod-like CeO2 catalyst (CuO/CeO2-R) with exposed CeO2 (110) crystal facet showed the highest catalytic performance in the CO-SCR reaction, achieving complete conversion of NO and 99 % conversion of CO at 250 °C. A series of characterizations reveal that the interaction between CuO and CeO2 with different crystal facets is crucial to regulating the interface structure and oxygen vacancy (O v ) content. During in situ DRIFTS analysis, it was found that the primary adsorption sites for CO are the Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites. The CuO/CeO2-R catalyst had the highest number of these sites. Furthermore, CuO/CeO2-R contained many O v sites, which promote NO dissociation and enhance its catalytic efficiency. This study offers insights into CO-SCR catalysis and the design of efficient catalysts by manipulating the exposed crystal facets of support to enhance CO-SCR activity. Keywords Oxygen vacancies Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites CO-SCR CeO2 crystal facets Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are major air pollutants. Hence, the reduction of NO x emissions is urgent and paramount for environmental protection [1]. Ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) is a widely employed flue gas denitrification technology in coal-fired power plants. However, industrial kilns often harbor residual CO that requires remediation [2–4]. Consequently, the selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR) within the exhaust gas emerges as a viable strategy to mitigate the risk of secondary pollution of NH3 and uphold environmentally sustainable practices [5–7]. Metal/oxide composite catalysts are extensively employed for CO-SCR [8], with oxides typically serving as supports (e.g., Al2O3 [9], TiO2 [10], ZrO2 [11], SiO2 [11], and CeO2 [8]) to disperse and stabilize the active metal. The resulting metal-support interactions and oxygen vacancies (O v s) promote the performance of the CO-SCR catalyst. Recent research indicates that CeO2 has a strong interfacial effect with the active metals (including Pt, Pd, and CuO) and is more likely to generating O v s [12,13]. As a result, CeO2-based catalysts show better performance for CO-SCR and are considered highly promising catalyst supports. Tailoring the morphology of various CeO2 structures to expose specific crystal facets is effective for fine-tuning its catalytic functions. Experiments show that the rod-like CeO2, with exposed (110)/(100) facets, and cube-like CeO2, with (100) facet, exhibit significantly enhanced activities in catalytic CO oxidation reactions compared to the octahedron-like CeO2, which mainly exposed the (111) facet [14,15]. Furthermore, Mai et al. [16] unveiled that CeO2 nanorods and nanocubes have superior oxygen storage capacity and redox properties compared to nanopolyhedral CeO2. Additionally, Zhang et al. [17] compared four shapes of CeO2 and found that O v s were the main active sites for adsorbing styrene and generating reactive oxygen species. However, pure CeO2 catalysts have limited activity for CO-SCR. Noble metals (e.g., Pd- [18], Pt- [19], Rh- [20], Ru- [21], and Ir-based [22]) have been studied for CO-SCR catalysts, but their large-scale application is limited due to the high cost. Therefore, many studies have been conducted on transition metals (Cu- [23], Fe- [24], Co– [25], Mn- [26], and Ni-based [24]) for CO-SCR. The CuO-CeO2 catalytic system exhibits promising activity in CO oxidation and NO reduction [27–29]. Cu and Ce undergo redox cycling, forming numerous O v s that facilitate the reaction. Specifically, Cu+ and O v s promote the adsorption of CO and NO, respectively, thereby enhancing the catalytic CO-SCR activity. Gu et al. [30] pretreated CuO/CeO2 catalysts with CO to expose more Cu+/Cu0 surface species and create additional O v s. O v s can dissociate NO, which is a key elementary step in the CO-SCR reaction, thereby enhancing NO-CO reactivity. However, a detailed investigation of how different exposed CeO2 crystal facets affect the number of O v s, the CuO-CeO2 interaction, and the catalytic performance of CO-SCR has yet to be conducted. This study focuses on creating a series of CuO/CeO2 catalysts with different CeO2 crystal facets to exposed, aiming to understand how the presence of O v s and the interaction between CuO and CeO2 affect the process of CO-SCR. The research involved various analyses, including in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), to investigate the relationship between catalyst structure, performance, and the reaction mechanism. The findings obtained help clarify how the exposed crystal facets and the loaded metals interact and how they synergistically affect the CO-SCR performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, purity > 99.0 %), cupric nitrate hexahydrate (Cu(NO3)2·xH2O, purity > 99.0 %), urea (CH4N2O, purity > 99 %), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, purity = 97.0 %) of analytical grade were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd and were used without further treatment. Detail information on experimental reagents and gases is listed in Table S1. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of the CeO2 supports CeO2-P: 2.17 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 3 g of urea were dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water (DI water), stirred for 30 min, and poured into a Teflon hydrothermal autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 10 h in an oven. After cooling to room temperature, the samples were washed three times by centrifugation with DI water and dried at 90 °C for 12 h. Support precursors were calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. The obtained CeO2 nanoparticles are denoted as CeO2-P. CeO2-R: 2.17 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 20 mL of DI water, followed by the addition of 60 mL of NaOH solution (6 M), and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. The solution was transferred into a Teflon hydrothermal autoclave and maintained at 120 °C for 24 h in an oven. The product was collected and washed alternately with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 90 °C for 12 h. Support precursors were calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1 [31]. The obtained CeO2 nanorods are denoted as CeO2-R. CeO2-C: 2.17 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 20 mL of DI water. Then, 60 mL of NaOH solution (6 M) was added to the above solution and stirred for 30 min. The solution was poured into a Teflon hydrothermal autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 24 h in an oven. The product was collected and washed alternately with DI water and ethanol, and dried at 90 °C for 12 h. Support precursors were calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1 [31]. The obtained CeO2 nanocubes are denoted as CeO2-C. 2.2.2 Synthesis of the CuO/CeO2 catalysts The CuO/CeO2 catalysts (10 wt% CuO) were prepared via an incipient wetness impregnation method using Cu(NO3)2 as a precursor. 3.0 g of CeO2-P was dispersed into 30 mL of DI water. After stirring for 30 min, 0.88 g of Cu(NO3)2·xH2O was added to the solution and stirred for an additional 6 h. The aqueous solvent was then removed by a rotary evaporator. The precursor was dried in an oven for 8 h. Finally, it was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 to obtain CuO/CeO2-P. CuO/CeO2-R and CuO/CeO2-C were prepared similarly to CuO/CeO2-P. The amounts of samples and reagents required for different loadings are shown in Table S2. 2.3 Characterization The morphological features of the sample surface were observed using a JSM-7610F scanning electron microscope (SEM) under a voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained using a JEM-2800 transmission electron microscope equipped with energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a Rigaku SmartLab SE diffractometer. The XRD patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 10 − 90° with a scan step of 10° min−1. The crystallite sizes of all catalysts were estimated using the Debye-Scherrer equation (D=Kλ/β cosθ). The surface areas of different catalysts were measured from the adsorption isotherms of N2 collected at −196 °C on the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer. Before measurement, all samples were heated and degassed at 300 °C for 8 h. The metal contents in the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110, America). Before the test, the samples were dissolved via microwave digestion pretreatment. A 0.05 g sample was dispersed into a 10 mL aqua regia in the microwave digestion tank. After pre-dissolution at 120 °C for 0.5 h, the samples were microwave-digested at 180 °C for 30 min. After the sample was cooled down to 60 °C, it was transferred to a 25 mL colourimetric tube and topped up to 25 mL with DI water for the ICP test. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were conducted by directly affixing 2 g of powder samples onto ordinary double-sided tape. The XPS spectra were detected by a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument, with Mg Ka X-rays as the excitation source at 300 W. The elemental content and valence information on the catalyst surface were analyzed. The binding energy of each element was corrected by the binding energy of C 1 s (284.8 eV) as the reference. The obtained data were fitted by XPS-peak software, and the valence molar ratio was calculated based on the peak area. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed using a Renishaw in Via with a wavelength of 532 nm. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) tests were conducted on a Finesorb-3010 chemical adsorption apparatus. 0.05 g sample was treated in Ar gas at 300 °C for 1 h, cooled to 50 °C, and heated to 800 °C under a flow of 5 vol% H2/Ar (10 mL min−1) at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. In situ DRIFTS analysis was conducted using a Bruker Tensor 27. 25 mg sample was initially pretreated with He gas at 300 °C for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature, with spectra collected during the cool-down phase serving as the background. The sample chamber was injected with gases (700 ppm NO, 1000 ppm CO, He as balance) at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for 40 min. After ventilation, the adsorption–desorption equilibrium was maintained at room temperature for 40 min. Spectra were collected by subtracting the corresponding background reference at a resolution of 4 cm−1, ranging from 650 to 4000 cm−1. Measurements were conducted at temperatures of 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, and 300 °C, with a heating rate of 5°C min−1. After reaching each temperature point, a waiting period of 10 − 15 min preceded the measurements. 2.4 Catalytic measurement The CO-SCR reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (inner diameter: 10 mm) with a thermocouple at its center. The catalysts were pretreated in a N2 stream at 300 °C for 1 h and cooled to room temperature. The catalytic activity of each 40 − 60 mesh catalyst was tested, and the experiments were performed at 50 − 400 °C. The NO conversion, CO conversion, and N2 selectivity of the catalysts were tested using a programmed temperature ramp with a temperature gradient of 50 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. Each measured temperature was held 25 °C to wait for the reaction to reach a steady state. The stability test was conducted continuously, and the product gas composition was analyzed every 1 h. The activity of the catalysis is reported with an error bar by averaging the test results of three repeated experiments. The gas feed gas consisted of 1000 ppm CO, 700 ppm NO, 5 vol% H2O (when needed), 0.5, 1, and 5 vol% O2 (when needed), with N2 as balance. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was fixed at 70 L g−1h−1. Gasmet Portable FT-IR Gas Analyzer was used for exhaust analysis to measure CO, NO, NO2, and N2O concentrations. The NO conversion, CO conversion, and N2 selectivity were evaluated using the following Eqs. (1) − (3): (1) N O c o n v e r s i o n % = NO in - NO out NO in × 100 % (2) C O c o n v e r s i o n % = CO in - CO out CO in × 100 % (3) N 2 selectivity % = 1 - 2 N 2 O in NO in - NO out × 100 % The reaction rate and activation energy (Ea) of the CO-SCR reaction over the CuO/CeO2 catalysts were measured using a catalyst mass of 1.0 g in the temperature range of 60 − 120 °C. To maintain NO conversion (X NO) below 20 %, the WHSVs used for CuO/CeO2 catalysts were 80, 85, and 90 L g−1h−1. The specific reaction rate was evaluated by the following formula (Eq. (4)): (4) R ate = F NO × X NO W cat = X NO W cat F NO F NO is the molar flow of NO in mol/min. W cat is the mass of the catalyst in g. Variations in X NO with respect to W/F NO were plotted, and the reaction rates were calculated at various temperatures from the slope of the linear portion (the “linear portion” refers to a straight line fitted by three points (Fig. S1)). Subsequently, a graph is plotted with ln(rate) as the vertical coordinate and temperature as the horizontal coordinate. The activation energy (Ea) was calculated using the Arrhenius equation. The turnover frequency (TOF) value, based on the number of reaction cycles per number of active Cu species per second, was calculated using Eq. (5) to compare the intrinsic activity of the catalysts [32–34]. (5) TOF = Q NO × X NO V m × n C u - surf Where QNO is the flow rate of NO (m3 s−1); Vm is the gas molar constant (m3 mol−1); X NO is the NO conversion at a certain temperature (%); and nCu-surf is the mole number of Cu atoms on the surfaces of catalysts (mol), which was estimated based on the BET and XPS value [35]. (6) n C u - surf = N C u - surf N A Where N Cu-surf is the number of Cu atoms on the surfaces of catalysts, and N A is the Avogadro constant (6.02 × 10-23 mol−1). The N Cu-surf is deduced from the following formula: (7) m catal · S surf = S C u - surf + S C e - surf + S O - surf = N C u - surf · S C u - single + N C e - surf · S C e - single + N O - surf · S O - single where m catal (g) is the mass of catalysts; S surf (m2 g−1) is the BET surface area of catalysts (Table 1 ); and S Cu-single (m2), S Ce-single (m2), and S O-single (m2) are the surface areas of single atoms, which were estimated by the hemispheric surface area formula (2πr2). The atomic radius employed for Ce, Cu, and O are as follows [32,36]: rCe = 1.65 × 10−10 m, rCu = 1.28 × 10−10 m, and rO = 6.4 × 10−11 m. The relative proportion between N Ce-surf, N Cu-surf, and N O-surf was calculated based on XPS, and relevant values are listed in Table S3. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the CeO2 supports The morphology, size, and composition of CeO2 were analyzed through TEM characterizations (Fig. S2a-c). The preparation temperature and the base concentration (urea and sodium hydroxide) affected the nanostructure of CeO2 in hydrothermal synthesis. Fig. 1 a-c demonstrate that the CeO2 supports are successfully synthesized with cube, rod, and normal particle morphologies, respectively. It is seen that some small nanocrystals decorate the CeO2-C cubes (Fig. 1a) and CeO2-R rods (Fig. 1b), which can be attributed to the dissolution and recrystallization processes of ceria nanostructures [37,38]. In Fig. 1c, the nanoparticles are uniformly distributed. These phenomena can be explained as follows: at low temperatures and low base concentrations, the dissolution/recrystallization rate is slow. Thus, the initially formed anisotropic Ce(OH)3 nuclei in the solution grow slowly to ceria nanoparticles. With the increased of the temperature and base concentration, the enhanced chemical potential drives the anisotropic growth of the Ce(OH)3 nuclei to nanorods; with further increase of the temperatures and the base concentrations, the Ce(OH)3 nuclei are oxidized into cubic ceria [39]. CeO2-C, with a particle size ranging from 100 to 150 nm (Table S4), exhibits a smooth surface (Fig. 1a), and tis TEM image (Fig. 1d) reveals an interplanar spacing of 0.27 nm for the (200) plane. In the TEM image of CeO2-R (Fig. 1e), distinct (220) and (400) lattice planes are observed, with interplanar spacings of 0.20 nm and 0.14 nm, respectively. CeO2-R displays diameters ranging from 8 to 15 nm and lengths spanning 200 to 300 nm, demonstrating a stacked and staggered distribution. CeO2-P shows clear (111) lattice planes with interplanar spacings of 0.31 nm, as shown in Fig. 1f. Based on the above analysis, CeO2-C is primarily enclosed by the (100) plane, while CeO2-P mainly exposes (111) crystal facet. Moreover, one-dimensional CeO2-R preferentially grows along (110) crystal direction and is enclosed by (100) and (110) crystal facets. CeO2-C and CeO2-R (insets of Fig. 1d and 1e) are polycrystalline diffractions, whereas CeO2-P (inset of Fig. 1f) is single-crystal diffraction. The major crystal facets exposed by CeO2-C, CeO2-R, and CeO2-P are the (100), (110), and (111) crystal facets, respectively, with their selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) shown in their insets of Fig. 1d-f (larger diffraction patterns are shown in Figs. S2d-f). Fig. 1g shows that CeO2-C, CeO2-R, and CeO2-P exhibit pure fluorite-type cubic structures (JCPDS 34–0394, space group Fm3m). Fig. 1h illustrates the synthesis process of CeO2-C, CeO2-R, and CeO2-P. The (110) crystal facet of CeO2 has an open structure with both Ce and O atoms in the top layer. In contrast, the surface layer is terminated by O, and the Ce layer underneath is inaccessible to the (110) surface. Such structure differences in the crystal facets can significantly affect the dispersion and valence of metals and metal oxides on their surfaces. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts 3.2.1 XRD and N2 adsorption–desorption analysis Fig. 2 a illustrates the XRD patterns of the CuO/CeO2 samples. The diffraction peaks match well with the pure fluorite-type cubic structure (space group Fm3m, JCPDS NO.34–0394). Two weak diffraction peaks at 35.4° and 38.5° over CuO/CeO2 samples are indexed to the ( 1 ‾ 11) and (111) planes of CuO (JCPDS 44–0706), respectively. Compared to the CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P samples, the diffraction peak intensity of CuO/CeO2-R is weaker, indicating a better dispersion of Cu. The lattice parameter of the catalysts is calculated based on Bragg’s equation, and the results are listed in Table 1. The lattice parameter of CeO2 decreases from 0.5420 nm (CeO2-R) to 0.5407 nm (CuO/CeO2-R) in position, while those of CuO/CeO2-C (0.5414 nm) and CuO/CeO2-P (0.5421 nm) decrease by 0.0002 nm and 0.0003 nm, respectively (Table 1 and Table S4). This is attributed to the partial incorporation of Cu2+ with a smaller ionic radius (r Cu 2+ = 0.73 Å) into the CeO2 lattice (r Ce 4+ = 0.94 Å), forming Ce1- x Cu x O2 solid solution [40–42]. The lattice parameter of the CuO/CeO2-R decreases significantly, suggesting more Cu species enter the lattice of CeO2-R. The CeO2-R before Cu loading possesses a higher surface area than that of CeO2-P and CeO2-C (Table S4), thus resulting in a higher dispersion of Cu species, which is consistent with the XRD analyses in Fig. 2a and 2b. The specific surface area of the CuO/CeO2 samples follows the order of CuO/CeO2-R>CuO/CeO2-C>CuO/CeO2-P, ranging from 10 to 71 m2 g−1 as listed in Table 1. The specific surface area of the samples decreased after loading with CuO, indicating that partial Cu species entered the support pores (Table 1 and Table S4). Type IV isotherms (Fig. 2c) with H1 hysteresis loops for CuO/CeO2-R, CuO/CeO2-C, and CuO/CeO2-P signify the presence of mesopores in the samples. The BJH pore distribution curves of samples are shown in the inset picture Fig. 2c. The majority of pores in the CuO/CeO2 samples were distributed within the range of 10 to 40 nm. The pore volume of CuO/CeO2-R (0.38 cm3 g−1) is the largest of the three samples (Table 1). The Cu content of CuO/CeO2-C, CuO/CeO2-R, and CuO/CeO2-P measured by ICP-OES were 6.91 wt%, 7.02 wt%, and 7.42 wt%, respectively. All are lower than the theoretical atomic weight content of Cu (10 wt%). The decrease in the weight content of Cu may be due to the loss of Cu precursor during the impregnation process. 3.2.2 TEM observation The CeO2 supports retained nanocube (Fig. 3 a1), nanorod (Fig. 3b1), and nanoparticle (Fig. 3c1) after loading with CuO. The obtained CuO/CeO2-C (Fig. 3a2), CuO/CeO2-R (Fig. 3b2), and CuO/CeO2-P (Fig. 3c2) also exposed (200), (110), and (111) crystal facets, respectively, which are consistent with the SEM results of CeO2 supports (Fig. 1a-c). TEM images of CuO/CeO2-C, CuO/CeO2-R, and CuO/CeO2-P reveal dispersed CuO. Notably, CuO/CeO2-R exhibits numerous white spots on the surface, which may correspond to CuO clusters. Comparatively, the high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images of CuO/CeO2-C (Fig. 3a3) and CuO/CeO2-P (Fig. 3c3) show defects distributed on CuO/CeO2-R (Fig. 3b3). To further investigate the distribution of Cu species, we did the EDS analyses for the three samples (Fig. 3a4-c4). The Cu, Ce, and O elements are uniformly distributed across the samples. The EDS mapping of the rod-like sample confirms a uniform dispersion of Ce and O elements, while Cu has a sparser distribution (Fig. 3b4). Notably, among the three samples, the mass fraction of Cu on CuO/CeO2-R is the highest (Fig. S2h), indicating its highest dispersion of Cu element. Therefore, the relatively larger BET surface area and higher density of surface defects not only enhance the dispersion of catalytically active species but also anchor Cu species to restrain their growth, which is consistent with the XRD and EDS mapping results. 3.2.3 H2-TPR and Raman analysis The redox properties of the samples were analyzed by H2-TPR (Fig. 4 a). The reduction temperatures of all three samples shifted to lower temperatures compared with those of pure CeO2 and CuO [43]. The electronic properties and structural environment of Cu species are greatly influenced by the interaction with CeO2 [44]. Importantly, CuO/CeO2-R shows the lowest reduction temperature (127 °C), indicating its oxygen species are most active. The peaks observed in the 120 to 127 °C range belong to dispersed subnanometer CuO x clusters, while those in the range of 153 to 166 °C are primarily attributed to the reduction of Ce1- x Cu x O2 solid solution. The peaks observed in the range of 183 to 190 °C are attributed to the reduction of the crystalline CuO species and that of the ceria surface [45]. More finely dispersed subnanometer CuO x clusters can form a larger CuO-CeO2 interface. Moreover, the Ce1- x Cu x O2 solid solution facilitates the creation of O v s and promotes the mobility of lattice oxygen [45]. Table 2 lists the hydrogen consumption of the three samples (with CuO as the standard sample). A1 and A2 represent the H2 consumption of Cu and Ce species, respectively. CuO/CeO2-R (1.78 mmol g−1) possessed the largest A1 compared to CuO/CeO2-C (1.59 mmol g−1) and CuO/CeO2-P (1.11 mmol g−1), indicating that CuO/CeO2-R exhibits better reduction properties. The H2 consumption of the three samples was much higher than the theoretical value for the reduction of pure CuO to Cu (0.375 mmol g−1) due to the partial reduction of CeO2 support and the hydrogen spillover effect [46]. Previous studies [39,45] have confirmed that surface O v s and defects on transition metal oxide supports play a crucial role in the dissociative adsorption of NO. The O v s and defects structure in the samples are examined by Raman scattering (Fig. 4b). The weak peaks at around 285 cm−1 are assigned to a second-order transverse acoustic mode (2TA). The strong peaks positioned at approximately 459 cm−1 correspond to the F 2g symmetric breathing mode of O atoms in the cubic-fluorite CeO2 structure (Ce-O-Ce vibration), and their location and shape can be regulated with the change of crystallite size [47]. The overlapping peaks from 520 to 650 cm−1 are attributed to the defect-induced mode (D), which is correlated with the deformation of the anionic lattice [48]. The D band is comprised of two components: the relatively weak peak at 590 cm−1 is ascribed to O v s, and the stronger peak at 610 cm−1 is assigned to the lattice distortions in the CeO2 lattice. Interestingly, the intensity of the D band in the Raman spectra of the CeO2 supports (Fig. S3) is low, and its intensity increase is most pronounced for CuO/CeO2-R. The concentration of defect sites in the catalysts can be quantitatively calculated via the relative intensity of the D band and F 2g (denoted as ID/IF 2g ). The ID/IF 2g ratio, indicative of structural defects, follows the order of CuO/CeO2-R>CuO/CeO2-C>CuO/CeO2-P (Table 2). The XRD pattern and Raman spectrum confirm the existence of abundant defects in the CuO/CeO2-R sample. Additionally, a new characteristic peak was observed at 1173 cm−1, attributed to the formation of O v s [49]. The lower O v concentration is likely due to the low occurrence of (1-α) CeO2 + α CuO↔Ce1- α CuO2- α + δ O v . The active component Cu2+ is hardly diffused into the CeO2 lattice, limiting the maximum available oxygen on the sample surface [46]. 3.2.3.1 XPS analysis The XPS spectra of all samples are presented in Fig. 5 . The survey spectra (Fig. 5a) indicate the presence of Ce, Cu, O, and C. The binding energy of C1s serves as a calibration reference. In Fig. 5b, the XPS spectra of Ce 3d for the three samples are deconvolved into eight peaks. The peaks of v′ and u′ are assigned to the characteristic peaks of Ce3+, while the peaks of v, v′′, v′′′, u, u′′, and u′′′ are assigned to the characteristic peaks of Ce4+. Fig. 5b shows that Ce3+ and Ce4+ co-exist in CuO/CeO2 samples. Pristine CeO2 supports show similar XPS spectra of Ce 3d (Fig. S4) and Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio (Table S5). As shown in the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) in Table 3 , Cu/CeO2-R contains more Ce3+ species compared with CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P, indicating more O v s are on CuO/CeO2-R, based on electroneutrality principles. The Ce3+ species promote the formation and mobility of surface-adsorbed oxygen species in the CuO/CeO2 samples [45]. The XPS spectrum of Cu 2p consists of two characteristic peaks and satellite peaks (Fig. 5c). The peaks around 928.1 and 947.2 eV correspond to the characteristic peaks of Cu+. In contrast, the peaks around 932.6 and 952.3 eV correspond to the characteristic peaks of Cu2+. The Cu+ and Cu2+ contents analyzed from the three samples indicate that Cu species on all three samples exist predominantly in the form of Cu2+. Combined with XPS analysis of Ce 3d, higher concentrations of Ce3+ can enhance the Cu site (Cu2+ ↔ Cu+) interactions. Therefore, CuO/CeO2-R (Cu+ concentration of 27.80 %) exhibits the highest redox performance. The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 5d) are deconvolved according to three different types of oxygen species, including lattice oxygen at ∼ 528.0 eV (Oα), chemisorbed oxygen species or O v s at ∼ 530.0 eV (Oβ), and adsorbed water molecules at ∼ 532.2 eV (Oγ) [5]. Only Oα and Oβ were observed on the pure CeO2 samples with different morphologies (Fig. S5). Shift of XPS characteristic peaks is related to electron gain and loss. As shown in Fig. 5d, the binding energy of Oα on CuO/CeO2-C (528.3 eV) is the lowest due to the highest electron gain by the O species; on the contrary, the binding energy of Oα on CuO/CeO2-P (528.9 eV) is the highest because of electron loss by the O species. As listed in Table 3, the higher Oβ/(Oγ + Oβ + Oα) surface ratio on CuO/CeO2-R than that on CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P suggest more abundant surface chemisorbed O species and O v s in the former. The higher concentration of Oβ on CuO/CeO2-R indicates that a higher content of Ce3+, which promotes the formation of active surface oxygen and O v s on the catalyst. Namely, more Cu+ undergoes interlayer migration to promote Cu2++Ce3+↔Cu++Ce4+ redox cycle reaction, accelerating interfacial O v s formation in the CuO/CeO2-R. 3.3 CO-SCR performance of the catalysts 3.3.1 Catalytic reduction of NO with CO The catalytic performances of the CuO/CeO2-R catalysts with varying CuO loadings in the CO-SCR reaction were studied (Fig. S6a). Increasing the CuO loading to 10 wt% significantly enhances the NO conversion of CuO/CeO2-R catalysts. However, further increasing CuO loading has little effect. Moreover, CuO was tested as a control sample, and its activity and selectivity were much lower than other samples (Figs. S6b-d). NO started reaction only above 300 °C on CuO. Meanwhile, CO reaction occurred on CuO at 200 °C and reached 100 % conversion at 400 °C. Therefore, the catalytic performance of CuO/CeO2 catalysts with different CeO2 supports is compared at a fixed CuO loading of 10 wt%. NO conversion reaches 50 % at approximately 100 °C (T 50 = ∼100 °C) on CuO/CeO2-R (Fig. 6 a), significantly lower than that of CuO/CeO2-C (approximately 120 °C) and CuO/CeO2-P (approximately 130 °C). Additionally, at 250 °C, CuO/CeO2-R exhibited higher N2 selectivity (>95 %) than CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P (Fig. 6b). The CO conversion of CuO/CeO2-R reached 96 % above 200 °C. In contrast, it needs 300 °C and 400 °C for CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P to reach the same conversion (Fig. 6c). Therefore, CuO/CeO2-R exhibited the highest catalytic performance. Figs. S7a-c shows the activity of the catalysts with an error bar by averaging the test results of three repeated experiments. Upon introducing 5 vol% O2 at 250 °C, the NO conversion over the three catalysts dropped sharply within 30 min (Fig. 6d). NO conversion of the three catalysts recovered to 34 − 49 % once decreasing O2 concentration to 1 vol%. Subsequently, NO conversion for all three catalysts increased when O2 concentration was further reduced to 0.5 vol%. The activity of all three catalysts recovered within 30 min upon cessation of the O2 flow. The CuO/CeO2-R catalyst is more resistant and recoverable to oxygen compared with that of CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P. The negative effect of O2 on the CO-SCR reaction activity may be due to the competitive adsorption of O2 and NO. Similarly, upon introducing 5 vol% H2O vapors into the reaction system, NO conversion on the CuO/CeO2-R catalyst decreased to around 90 % at 250 °C (Fig. 6e). In comparison, CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P exhibited a more pronounced decrease. All catalysts gradually recover NO conversion upon discontinuation of H2O vapor. As shown in Fig. 6f, no significant change in CO conversion was observed for the three catalysts when 5 vol% H2O vapor was introduced into the reaction, suggesting H2O vapor does not affect catalysts obviously. The stability of CuO/CeO2-C, CuO/CeO2-R, and CuO/CeO2-P was tested at 250 °C. As shown in Fig. 6g, the CuO/CeO2-R catalyst exhibited good stability under the test conditions, maintaining NO conversion at around 99 % for 24 h. The CO conversion and N2 selectivity of CuO/CeO2-R were also the highest among the three catalysts in the stability test (Fig. S8). In addition, the activity of the CuO/CeO2-R catalysts was further tested from high to low temperatures, as shown in Fig. S9. The NO conversion and N2 selectivity are the same as the ones tested from low to high temperature, demonstrating the catalyst does not change at high temperature. 3.3.1.1 Apparent activation energies and TOF of the catalysts Specific reaction rates and apparent activation energies (Ea) were calculated to compare the intrinsic activity of CuO/CeO2-C, CuO/CeO2-R, and CuO/CeO2-P catalysts. Arrhenius plots were obtained at NO conversions less than 20 % to exclude mass and heat transfer effects (Fig. S10) [50]. The TOF and Ea for CuO/CeO2-C, CuO/CeO2-R, and CuO/CeO2-P are calculated and listed in Table 4 . Among the three CuO/CeO2 catalysts, CuO/CeO2-R exhibits the highest catalytic performance, with a TOF of 0.10 s−1. In general, CuO/CeO2-R exhibits a faster reaction rate than the other catalysts within the range of 50 − 400 °C (Fig. 6h). Notably, the specific reaction rate on CuO/CeO2-R is 3.04 × 10−3 mol−1 NO g−1 cat h−1 at 100 °C, about 1.5 to 2 times higher than CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P, respectively, as shown in Fig. 6h. Ea follows the order of CuO/CeO2-R<CuO/CuO2-C<CuO/CuO2-P, as shown in Fig. 6i. The CuO/CeO2-R catalyst has the lowest Ea value of 8.48 kJ mol−1 (Table 4), indicating that its kinetic barrier of CO-SCR reaction is the lowest. This trend agrees with the activity trend for NO conversion, underscoring the influence of CeO2-exposed crystal facets on Ea. Furthermore, the reactivity and spectroscopic results can be rationalized by a reaction mechanism proposed based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model, which focuses on the observed major NO and CO species (Eqs.(8) − (10)). (8) NO + * ⟷ K NO N O * (9) CO + * ⟷ K CO C O * (10) N O * + C O * ⟷ k 1 2 N 2 + C O 2 The symbol * describes active sites, NO* and CO* represent adsorbed NO and CO, respectively. In addition, the partial pressure influences the catalytic activity. Fig. 7 shows the TOF as a function of NO partial pressure and CO partial pressure at 120 °C. Solid points in Fig. 7 are experimental value, while the hollow points are calculated values. Although the NO conversion decreases with CO partial pressure (Fig. S11a), the reaction rate (TOF) increases (Fig. 7a) at higher CO partial pressures. Calculations of reaction equilibrium constants versus reaction rates via equation (Eq. S1) yielded KNO>KCO, indicating that NO molecules adsorb more strongly than CO molecules on the surface sites. Namely, NO molecules occupy a large portion of the surface. This is consistent with the result in Fig. 7b, which states that TOF increases with increasing NO pressure. In addition, as shown in Fig. S11b, the NO conversion increases with the increase of NO partial pressure, which indicates that the higher the NO partial pressure, the stronger the CO-SCR reaction activity. The catalytic performance of CuO/CeO2-R was compared with several state-of-the-art catalysts reported in the literature, as shown in Table 5 . The catalytic performance of CuO/CeO2-R is superior due to a higher TOF at a lower reaction temperature (120 °C). The above characterization provides an in-depth understanding of the relationship between the structure and activity of CuO/CeO2 catalysts. The XRD results indicate that Cu2+, with a smaller ionic radius, infiltrates the CeO2 lattice, forming Ce1- x Cu x O2 solid solutions. Meanwhile, the H2-TPR results reveal the presence of finely dispersed subnanometer CuO x clusters and Ce1- x Cu x O2 solid solutions on the CuO/CeO2-R. In addition, these clusters and solid solutions create a higher density of CuO-CeO2 interfaces. The existence of Cu+ species promoted the generation of asymmetric O v s at the CuO-CeO2 interface, and the relative content of Cu+ in the CuO/CeO2 catalysts is determined by Cu 2p XPS spectra. Cu+ can form a catalytic Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface with two redox sites (Cu+, Ce3+) sites. The Raman and Ce 3d XPS results show that the formation of the solid solution promotes the concentration of O v in CeO2, which facilitates the activation of gaseous oxygen and the migration of lattice oxygen, producing more reactive oxygen species and ultimately achieving high catalytic performance. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS analysis The reaction mechanism was studied using in situ DRIFTS analysis. As shown in Fig. 8 a-c, dense bands in the range of 1297 − 1609 cm−1 are observed for all three catalysts, attributing to the formation of nitrite and nitrate species, including monodentate nitrate (1297 and 1481 cm−1) and linear nitrite (1427 cm−1). The peak at 1605 cm−1 disappears with increasing temperature, indicating the instability of NO x species at high temperatures [28,58,59]. It is worth noting that CuO/CeO2-R (Fig. 6b) exhibits a strong peak at 1748 cm−1, attributed to the presence of the (NO)2 dimer [60,61]. The peak intensity gradually decreases with increasing temperature, indicating that the (NO)2 dimer is intermediate at low temperatures. The conversion of NO to the (NO)2 dimer is related to the surface-adsorbed oxygen. The higher content of adsorbed oxygen on the surface is correlated to the greater intensity of the (NO)2 dimer peak. The NO molecules are decomposed on O v s into [N] and [O] radicals, followed by recombination with other [N] species to form N2O. The N2O species correspond to the peaks in the range of 2200 − 2240 cm−1 [62]. In CO-SCR, N2O, N2, and NO2 are formed through the adsorbed active NO x intermediates [5]. The N2O peaks on CuO/CeO2-R are more pronounced than those on CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-P in the 100 − 150 °C range and almost disappear after 200 °C. The N2O peaks are more pronounced in the 100 − 150 °C range than at 200 °C. This also indicates that the N2 selectivity (Fig. 6b) of CuO/CeO2-C and CuO/CeO2-R is superior to that of CuO/CeO2-R before 200 °C. The results of CO adsorption are depicted in Fig. 8d-f. All three catalysts exhibit an adsorption peak at 1062 cm−1, corresponding to the monodentate carbonate. Additionally, the symmetric stretching vibrational modes of carboxylates are observed in the range of 1291 − 1469 cm−1, while the asymmetric stretching oscillations of carboxylates are observed in the range of 1482 − 1656 cm−1. The peak at 2112 cm−1 is attributed to Cu+–CO, indicating that Cu+ is an important intermediate in the reaction process. The intensity of the Cu+–CO peak significantly decreases with increasing temperature. Peaks in the range of 2300 − 2400 cm−1 correspond to gaseous CO2, suggesting that the reaction between Cu+–CO and oxygen on the catalyst surface produces CO2. To assess the reactivity of CO+NO on CuO/CeO2-R, we conducted in situ DRIFTS experiments for the reaction of CO with pre-adsorbed NO (Fig. 8g) and the reaction of NO with pre-adsorbed CO (Fig. 8h), respectively. The pre-adsorbed NO on the catalyst exists in the form of bridging bidentate nitrate (1029 cm−1), chelating bidentate nitrite (1258 and 1579 cm−1), and linear nitrite (1408 cm−1), as shown in Fig. 8g. When NO flow is switched to CO flow, the peak intensities of various nitrate species including N2O4 decrease with increasing reaction time. Gaseous CO adsorption saturates after 18 min, with peaks corresponding to CO2 observed within 2200 − 2400 cm−1 and a small amount of carboxylate salts formed. This indicates Cu+ can adsorb CO, and CO can potentially reduce Cu2+ to Cu+ and generate O v s. The nitrate species on the catalyst undergo rapid reaction with the highly active Cu+–CO, ultimately yielding N2 and CO2. As shown in Fig. 8h, when CO is pre-adsorbed on the catalyst in the form of carboxylate salts before introducing NO, the peak intensity of carboxylate salts decreases, and the CO2 peak increases. Additionally, an increase in the N2O4 peak at 1750 cm−1 suggests that NO is adsorbed on O v s, forming free [N] and free [O] radicals. It is deduced that the adsorbed oxygen species dissociate on the catalyst surface to release O, reacting with gaseous CO to generate CO2 or reacting with highly active Cu+–CO to form carboxylate salts. 3.5 Proposed mechanism for the CO-SCR reaction Based on the in situ DRIFTS analysis, a reaction mechanism is proposed for the CO-SCR reaction. Firstly, surface O v s can adsorb NO and activate the N-O bond, promoting NO dissociation. Secondly, CO adsorbed on the active sites can react with surface oxygen atoms generated from NO dissociation, forming CO2 and regenerating O v s. Based on the above characterization results, the CO-SCR reaction on CuO/CeO2-R may follow the L-H mechanism (Fig. 9 ), comprising six reaction stages. The Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites in CuO/CeO2-R play crucial roles as the adsorption/activation sites for NO and CO. Upon exposure of the CuO/CeO2-R catalyst to the NO+CO reaction stream, NO and CO are adsorbed on Ce3+ and Cu+ of Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites, respectively (Eqs. (11) and (12)). The activated Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites promote NO dissociation and the formation of Cu2+-O-Ce4+ and nitrogen radicals ([N]) (Eq. (13)). The [N] can combine with NO or another [N] to produce N2O and N2 (Eq. (14)). The adsorbed CO binds the O atoms from Cu2+-O-Ce4+ and regenate Cu+-O v -Ce3+ (Eqs. (15) and (16)), thus completing the catalytic circle. (11) C u + - O V - C e 3 + + N O g → C u + - O V - C e 3 + - N O (12) CO ( g ) + C u + - O V - C e 3 + - N O → C O - C u + - O V - C e 3 + - N O (13) CO - C u + - O V - C e 3 + - N O → C O - C u 2 + - O - C e 4 + + [ N ] (14) N + N → N 2 ( g ) (15) CO - C u 2 + - O - C e 4 + → C O 2 ( g ) + C u + - O V - C e 3 + (16) 2 C O - C u + - O V - C e 3 + - N O → C u + - O V - C e 3 + + 2 C O 2 ( g ) + N 2 ( g ) 4 Conclusion The CuO/CeO2 catalysts with different exposing crystal facets of ((100), (110), and (111)) are successfully synthesized by the hydrothermal method followed by impregnation. The interaction between CeO2 with different exposed crystal facets and active metal CuO affects the catalytic CO-SCR performance of the catalysts. Among the three CuO/CeO2 catalysts with different exposed crystal facets, CuO/CeO2-R with exposed (110) crystal facets shows the highest catalytic activity, achieving 100 % NO and CO conversion at 250 °C. The in situ DRIFTS investigation over CuO/CeO2-R indicates that NO dissociation is crucial for the catalytic reaction. Each Cu+-O v -Ce3+ site has two redox sites (Cu+ and Ce3+); Cu+ can adsorb CO, while Ce3+ can adsorbs and dissociates NO into O and [N]. Meanwhile, the O v s facilitate the migration of lattice oxygen to produce more reactive oxygen species. Subsequently, the released O from NO dissociation reacts with CO to form CO2 and regenerate the O v s, completing the catalytic cycle. This work provides a new perspective for designing efficient CO-SCR catalysts via modulating the exposed crystal facets of the supports. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR) has a significant impact on the sustainable development of the environment. It is crucial to design efficient low-temperature catalysts to overcome the challenges associated with the industrialization of CO-SCR. Herein, we present CuO/CeO2 catalysts with three different exposed crystal facets of CeO2 ((100), (110), and (111)) synthesized by a hydrothermal method followed by impregnation for CO-SCR. Among the three CuO/CeO2 catalysts, CuO loaded on rod-like CeO2 catalyst (CuO/CeO2-R) with exposed CeO2 (110) crystal facet showed the highest catalytic performance in the CO-SCR reaction, achieving complete conversion of NO and 99 % conversion of CO at 250 °C. A series of characterizations reveal that the interaction between CuO and CeO2 with different crystal facets is crucial to regulating the interface structure and oxygen vacancy (O v ) content. During in situ DRIFTS analysis, it was found that the primary adsorption sites for CO are the Cu+-O v -Ce3+ interface sites. The CuO/CeO2-R catalyst had the highest number of these sites. Furthermore, CuO/CeO2-R contained many O v sites, which promote NO dissociation and enhance its catalytic efficiency. This study offers insights into CO-SCR catalysis and the design of efficient catalysts by manipulating the exposed crystal facets of support to enhance CO-SCR activity.
